gun_control_and_gun_rights_176: President Obama plans to announce a comprehensive effort to address gun violence at a press conference Wednesday. He will call on Congress to ban military-style assault weapons and high-capacity magazines, and he will ask for universal background checks. Up to 19 separate actions he can take without Congressional approval will also be included. These actions could include tougher measures on gun trafficking, freeing up federal agencies to conduct more research on gun control, and giving schools flexibility to use grants to improve safety. The White House has been vague about what exactly Obama will include in his executive orders, but they are expected to focus on universal background checks, a ban on assault weapons and limiting ammunition magazines to 10 rounds or fewer, and more anti-bullying efforts. The White House is also expected to order federal agencies to conduct more research on gun use and crimes, the lobbyist said, and on mental health, Obama will focus on more availability of mental health services, training more school counselors and mental health professionals, and mental health first aid training for first responders.
national_security_374: On Tuesday, it was reported that Special Counsel Robert Mueller had raised the possibility of a subpoena for President Donald Trump if he refuses to talk to investigators in the Russia probe. The news was based on a former lawyer for the president who revealed the information on Tuesday. John Dowd, Trump’s former lead attorney, told the Associated Press that Mueller raised the possibility of a subpoena during a meeting with Trump’s legal team in March. “This isn’t some game,” Dowd said at the time. However, the suggestion that Mueller could try to compel an appearance by the president only escalated tensions over the investigation into allegations of collusion between the Trump campaign and Russian officials ahead of the 2016 election. Meanwhile, on Monday, the New York Times obtained a lengthy list of questions that Mueller and his team have prepared for the president. The questions cover a wide range of topics, including the president’s interactions with key figures in the Russia probe, his businesses, and his discussions with his personal lawyer, Michael Cohen, about a possible Moscow real estate deal.
gun_control_and_gun_rights_651: President Obama is reviewing recommendations from a task force on gun violence and is expected to make some public later this week. The task force was led by Vice President Joe Biden and included members of the House Democratic Gun Violence Prevention Task Force. One of the recommendations being considered is a ban on assault weapons and high-capacity ammunition clips. Obama has also mentioned the possibility of tightening background checks on prospective gun buyers. The NRA has vowed to fight any gun restrictions tooth and nail.
elections_442: FBI reopens Clinton email investigation 8 days before election, Clinton calls it 'unprecedented' and 'disturbing' The FBI has reopened its investigation into Hillary Clinton's email use, just eight days before the U.S. presidential election. The move was prompted by the discovery of new emails related to the investigation. Clinton called the decision "unprecedented" and "disturbing," and said there was "no case here." The FBI's director, James Comey, announced the move in a letter to congressional committee chairmen. The news has put Clinton on the defensive and raised questions about the motives behind the move. The Clinton campaign has accused the FBI of violating laws and interfering in the election. The FBI has not released any details about the new evidence or its significance.
middle_east_450: The Obama administration is preparing to go forward with a military strike against Syria after evidence was presented to Congress that suggests the Assad regime was behind the chemical weapons attack in Damascus. The UK parliament has rejected military action in Syria, but France has indicated it will still support strikes. Germany has also said it is not considering military action. While the intelligence does not tie Mr. Assad directly to the attack, officials say that the chemical weapons attack was more devastating than intended. The administration is undeterred by criticism from Congress and the British parliament and plans to go ahead with strikes against Syria.
immigration_814: On Sunday, President Trump announced that DACA, the program that shields young undocumented immigrants from deportation, is "probably dead." Trump tweeted that Democrats don't really want a solution and are only using the program as a bargaining chip to get more money for their pet projects, including the military. Meanwhile, Republicans and Democrats are at odds over funding the government. The deadline for a funding deal is midnight Friday, and if no agreement is reached, the government will shut down. Trump also commented on immigration, saying that he wants immigrants coming into the country to be based on merit, not lotteries. He also criticized the idea of "chain migration," where family members of legal immigrants can also come to the US.
us_congress_237: Senate Democrats have blocked a bill to keep the federal government running and fund the Children ’ s Health Insurance Program for the next six years. They have, that is, partially shut the government down, and they have taken this step not because of any strong objection to provisions of the funding bill but because it omits a provision they want: an amnesty for illegal immigrants who came to our country as minors. Most Republicans favor this amnesty, but the parties have been unable to agree on what other policies, such as restrictions on follow-on immigration from the amnesty, should be coupled with it. The Democrats are trying to spin the media and the public into thinking that the shutdown is the Republicans’ responsibility.
gun_control_and_gun_rights_216: President Obama plans to unveil a comprehensive gun control package on Wednesday, which includes measures like banning assault weapons and high-capacity ammunition magazines, mandating universal background checks for gun purchases, and increasing funding for mental health services. However, the chances of the package passing Congress are uncertain, with Republicans controlling the House and many Democrats in the Senate expressing hesitation or opposition to the proposals. The Newtown shooting in December has galvanized support for gun control, but the divisive issue is likely to remain a focus of political debate in the coming months.
abortion_312: Missouri lawmakers have passed a bill that would ban abortions at eight weeks of pregnancy or later in all cases except for medical emergencies. The legislation is one of the most restrictive in the country and has no exceptions for rape or incest. The bill was passed by the Missouri House in a 110-44 vote and by the Senate in a 24-10 vote. The measure now goes to Governor Mike Parson. The bill is similar to one passed in Alabama earlier this month that bans all abortions at any stage of pregnancy. The anti-abortion movement has gained momentum in recent years with the election of conservative Supreme Court justices, including President Trump's appointees, Neil Gorsuch and Brett Kavanaugh.
economy_and_jobs_228: The US unemployment rate dropped by 0.2 percentage points in November to 7.7%, the lowest it has been since December 2008. The Labor Department reported that the US economy added 146,000 jobs in November, beating analysts' expectations. The job gains were spread across various sectors including retail, health care and professional services. The BLS said that Hurricane Sandy did not have a significant impact on the national employment and unemployment estimates. However, many Americans dropped out of the labor force, leading to a decline in the number of unemployed persons. Despite the progress made, the US still faces a tough fiscal cliff, which could lead to a recession if not addressed.
immigration_469: The House is likely to take up some immigration legislation this year, but it’s not clear what that will look like. The House Republican leadership has released a set of principles, but they haven’t decided yet whether to take action. House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi (D-CA) has also been pushing for a bill to fix the immigration system. The Senate passed a comprehensive immigration bill in June, but it’s unclear if that will have an impact on the House. In the meantime, House Republicans are continuing to hold private meetings with Senate Democrats in hopes of finding a deal.
politics_35: Mitt Romney, who is set to begin his first term in the Senate on Thursday, launched a blistering attack on President Donald Trump in a Washington Post op-ed published Tuesday night. In the op-ed, Romney said that Trump’s leadership is undermining the country, and he has not risen to the mantle of the office. Trump fired back on Twitter Wednesday morning, calling the op-ed disrespectful and unproductive. Romney, the 2012 Republican presidential nominee, has been openly critical of Trump in the past but has also praised some of his policies and his appointment of conservative judges and Cabinet members. Trump also publicly supported Romney’s bid for the Senate in Utah.
elections_187: The Clinton campaign is ramping up its attacks on WikiLeaks and the Russian government after the release of more emails stolen from John Podesta. The Clinton campaign called on the media to focus on the national security implications of the hack, rather than the political minutiae. The campaign claimed that Trump and his advisers had conspired to aid the Russians and accused them of using Moscow talking points. Trump responded by suggesting that Clinton was using the emails to distract from his own missteps. The debate between the two candidates is set for Wednesday in Las Vegas.
federal_budget_449: The U.S. Treasury Department is warning Congress that it will run out of money by October 17th and will not be able to pay all its bills. Treasury Secretary Jack Lew has said that failing to raise the debt ceiling will have “catastrophic” effects on the economy. President Obama has refused to negotiate with Congress over the debt ceiling, and Senate Republican leader Orrin Hatch has accused him of trying to whip up uncertainty in the markets. The debt-ceiling battle has already led to a partial government shutdown that has been going on for 12 days.
china_164: Hong Kong Chief Executive Carrie Lam announced the withdrawal of a controversial extradition bill on Wednesday, citing the need to allay public concerns and bring an end to months of violence. The bill, which would have allowed China to extradite suspects from Hong Kong, sparked a pro-democracy movement that has reverberated around the world. Despite the bill’s withdrawal, protesters have continued to call for five other demands, including an independent investigation into police brutality and fully democratic elections. The protests have highlighted the erosion of democratic freedoms in Hong Kong and put China on the defensive.
immigration_690: The Senate Judiciary Committee has given final approval to a sweeping immigration reform bill, sending it to the Senate floor for consideration. The bill, known as the “Gang of Eight” immigration reform bill, would create a pathway to citizenship for 11 million undocumented immigrants, invest billions in new border security measures and overhaul the legal immigration system. If enacted, it would be the first overhaul of the nation’s immigration policy since 1986. The committee did not approve two gay rights amendments.
elections_727: The GOP's chances of gaining control of the Senate have increased to their highest yet, with the Des Moines Register predicting a seven point lead for Republican Joni Ernst in Iowa. If Republicans win eight seats, they would have a majority of 53 or more, making it more difficult for Democrats to regain control of the Senate in 2016. Many of the races are in swing states that Obama won in 2012 and have low approval ratings for the President.
politics_703: 6.Donald Trump and a top Republican lawmaker, Rep. Devin Nunes, are at odds over the release of a memo that Trump claims will exonerate him in the ongoing Russia investigation. Trump has already released a memo that he says was written by Republicans on the House Intelligence Committee and that accuses the FBI of using a salacious anti-Trump dossier to obtain a warrant to monitor a Trump associate. However, the committee's top Democrat, Rep. Adam Schiff, has accused the majority of perpetuating a false narrative and has vowed to release his own memo rebutting the Republican memo. The release of the Republican memo has already caused a rift between the White House and law enforcement, with former FBI director James Comey calling it a "blatant political act" and former CIA director John Brennan calling it "a misrepresentation of the facts.
middle_east_385: The U.S. military is conducting airstrikes in Iraq on Sunni extremist militants, including the Islamic State. The airstrikes began three days ago and have hit several targets, including an armored personnel carrier, a truck, and a mortar position. The airstrikes are limited in scope and will continue to be limited until the Iraqi government forms an inclusive government. The U.S. plans to stay vigilant and will take action if there is a direct threat to U.S. personnel or facilities in Iraq. The U.S. is also providing weapons to Kurdish security forces. President Obama has authorized both humanitarian drops and airstrikes against Islamic State militants in Iraq.
national_security_839: Former CIA director John Brennan has had his security clearance revoked by President Donald Trump, who cited “unfounded and outrageous allegations” made by the former director against Trump’s administration. Trump has also threatened to revoke the clearances of other former high-ranking national security officials, including former FBI Director James Comey, former Director of National Intelligence James Clapper, former National Security Agency Director Michael Hayden, former national security adviser Susan Rice, former FBI attorney Lisa Page, former Deputy Attorney General Sally Yates, former FBI Deputy Director Andrew McCabe, and former associate deputy attorney general Bruce Ohr. While Trump claims the move is part of a broader effort to suppress freedom of speech and punish critics, many have criticized the move as an attack on free speech and political dissent.
world_23: President Obama paid his respects to Nelson Mandela during a memorial service in Johannesburg on Tuesday. While greeting world leaders, Obama shook hands with Cuban President Raul Castro, sparking controversy. The U.S. has maintained an economic embargo on Cuba for over 50 years. Mandela's death resulted in a moment of truth for dictators and oppressors, as they were forced to sit through a celebration of democracy and equality. Obama's speech clearly rebuked dictators who defy the will of their people.
federal_budget_318: The Pentagon is bracing for the removal of 800,000 civilian workers in March, as part of the sequester. The cuts will save $4 billion to $5 billion if extended through the end of the budget year. The across-the-board spending reductions would put the U.S. military on a path toward a hollow force. In his congressional notification letter, Defense Secretary Leon Panetta wrote that the sequester would save $4 billion to $5 billion if extended through the end of the budget year, but it would seriously erode readiness across the force. The furloughs would begin in late April and would save $4 billion to $5 billion if extended through the end of the budget year. The sequester is a result of the 2011 agreement to raise the federal borrowing limit, intended to motivate Congress to negotiate a comprehensive deficit reduction deal.
justice_department_407: The Treasury Department’s inspector general for tax administration has released a report that the IRS unfairly targeted conservative groups for extra scrutiny, including tea party groups, for more than 18 months. IRS officials used inappropriate criteria to single out these groups for review and resulted in significant delays in processing, according to the report. The IRS has been under fire for its actions, and some have called for a full investigation. The report does not conclude that the extra scrutiny was motivated by partisan politics.
politics_71: The FBI director he fired wrote a memo accusing Trump of trying to hinder the investigation into their former national security advisor, Michael Flynn. The memo, which Trump has denied, reportedly says Trump asked Comey to drop the probe into Flynn. If true, it could be evidence of obstruction of justice. The memo was apparently written shortly after an Oval Office meeting on Feb. 14. Trump has repeatedly denied any wrongdoing and the White House disputes the memo's accuracy. The Republican-controlled Congress has not held Trump's administration accountable.
impeachment_392: In this article, it is reported that the impeachment trial of President Donald Trump is set to begin in the Senate. The article discusses the role of Chief Justice John Roberts, who will preside over the trial. It also discusses the evidence presented by the House impeachment managers and the potential witnesses that may be called. The article notes that the outcome of the trial will depend on the votes of the senators and that the president will likely be acquitted.
white_house_197: Summary: Amidst the ongoing controversy over the Comey-Trump tapes, the House Intelligence Committee has sent a letter to the White House demanding any recordings that might exist of the conversations between President Trump and former FBI director James Comey. The request came after Comey testified before the Senate Intelligence Committee on Thursday that he hoped such tapes existed, and that he believed it was possible that a special counsel could be appointed based on the testimony. The committee also requested documents related to the meeting, and in a separate letter, Senator Chuck Grassley, the head of the Senate Judiciary Committee, asked for any memos Comey wrote documenting the meeting, which were later leaked to the press. The White House has not yet responded to the request, and it is unclear whether any tapes exist.
elections_400: Bernie Sanders has just won the popular vote in Nevada and is now the front-runner in the Democratic presidential race. He has also won the popular vote in each of the first three contests. In South Carolina, Sanders is facing off against former Vice President Joe Biden, who is the favorite among African American voters. However, Sanders has gained ground among men, women, whites, Latinos, union households, and non-union households, as well as among voters of all ages, except those over 65. He has also called for progressive policies such as Medicare for all, tuition-free public education, universal day care, and a Green New Deal. Biden, Amy Klobuchar, Pete Buttigieg, and Mike Bloomberg have scoffed at these ideas as too radical, too bold, too costly, and too ambitious. However, Sanders' coalition is diverse and broad, and his policies offer hope for many Americans.
isis_417: In his speech, President Obama announced a plan to combat ISIS in the Middle East. The plan includes airstrikes in Iraq and Syria, as well as supporting moderate Syrian opposition groups. However, the Obama administration is facing complications as it works to assemble support at home and abroad. Some countries, such as Turkey and Saudi Arabia, are hesitant to join the coalition due to concerns about their own national security interests. Meanwhile, the U.S. is facing criticism for downplaying the conflict by not using the term "war" to describe the operation. The CIA has estimated that ISIS has as many as 31,500 fighters across Iraq and Syria. The U.S. intelligence officials are struggling to track American and European-born fighters who travel to the Middle East to join ISIS due to different approaches to sharing information and homeland security from their European counterparts.
supreme_court_220: Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Chuck Grassley (R-Iowa) said in a statement that Ford 's testimony would reflect her personal knowledge and memory of events, adding that nothing the FBI or any other investigator does would have any bearing on what Dr. Ford tells the committee. Meanwhile, Ford 's lawyers sent a letter to Grassley stating that their client would not appear at the hearing unless an FBI investigation is conducted first.
justice_department_583: The Justice Department investigated several news organizations for leaked classified information. The investigation of Fox News reporter James Rosen led to a search for his personal e-mails, phone records, and security badge tracking. The investigation of Associated Press phone records led to a grand jury investigation but no charges were filed. The Republican-controlled House Judiciary Committee is looking into whether Attorney General Eric Holder lied under oath earlier this month when he said he was never involved in the potential prosecution of the press. Holder took part in discussions about seeking a search warrant for Rosen’s e-mails and phone records. President Obama ordered a review of government practices in investigating leaks of secret information.
federal_budget_554: The White House is gearing up for a battle over automatic spending cuts set to take effect March 1. The cuts, part of a law passed in 2011, were supposed to be avoided in the fiscal cliff deal, but Congress managed to delay them by two months. Now, with less than two weeks to go, lawmakers face another countdown before the cuts are scheduled to begin. The across-the-board cuts, aimed at reducing the deficit by $ 1.2 trillion over the next decade, are opposed by Democrats, who want to replace the budget cuts with a combination of increased tax revenue, ending agriculture subsidies and reducing defense spending after the war in Afghanistan ends. Republicans, including Sen. John Barrasso, say the country should be prepared for the sequester and its massive spending cuts to kick in next month.
national_security_556: Robert Mueller, the special counsel investigating President Donald Trump and his campaign, on Friday filed a confidential memo accusing former campaign chairman Paul Manafort of lying to investigators. The memo also accused Manafort of attempting to hurt the Clinton campaign in key states. In a separate development, U.S. Special Counsel Robert Mueller filed a sentencing memo for former Trump campaign lawyer Michael Cohen, who pleaded guilty to lying to Congress and campaign finance violations. The memo described Cohen's "substantial" cooperation with the investigation. The memo also provided more details on the nature of Cohen's cooperation, including his help in identifying individuals who may have been involved in Russian collusion with the campaign. Cohen is due to be sentenced next Wednesday in New York.
world_771: Over the past week, the search for hundreds of Nigerian schoolgirls kidnapped by Boko Haram has intensified. The U.S. and other Western powers have joined the search, with the U.S. deploying a small team of military personnel to help assess the situation. The team is composed of roughly 10 uniformed soldiers from AFRICOM headquarters in Stuttgart, Germany, who will be logistics and communications experts. The team will not carry out a rescue mission, but will advise Nigerian officials. The French government has also sent security service agents to help track down the Boko Haram terror group and its hostages. The pledges of support have come amid mounting frustration among parents of the kidnapped girls, who are worried about what Boko Haram leader Abubakar Shekau and his army of jihadist fighters might do to their daughters in the days to come. The group has vowed to sell into slavery the roughly 275 kidnapped teenage girls.

elections_298: The Democratic caucus in Iowa has concluded, with Pete Buttigieg and Bernie Sanders in a virtual tie for first place. The race is too close to call, but it appears Sanders may have won the popular vote. Elizabeth Warren is currently in third place. With 97 percent of precincts reporting, Sanders led Buttigieg by about 6,000 votes. The chairman of the Iowa Democratic Party, Troy Price, said the final results should be released by Thursday morning.
supreme_court_821: The Supreme Court on Monday ruled that only one of four provisions in Arizona's controversial immigration law would stand. The remaining provisions, including a requirement that police check the immigration status of anyone they suspect to be in the country illegally, were struck down as infringing on federal authority. The decision was widely seen as a victory for President Obama and a setback for Mitt Romney, who had supported the Arizona law and now must walk a tightrope on immigration policy. The ruling also paved the way for similar legislation in other states and could anger Latinos, a key voting bloc for Obama. The court also extended its term until Thursday, signaling it would issue its much-anticipated ruling on Mr. Obama's health care law then.
north_korea_98: North Korea is celebrating the birthday of its founder, Kim Il-sung, with festivities in Pyongyang despite international tensions over its nuclear weapons program. The Kim Jong-un regime has recently stepped up its threats against South Korea and the United States, but has not yet given any notice before attacking. U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry has urged North Korea to show its seriousness about denuclearization if it wants to hold talks. North Korea has responded by warning that it would not give any advance notice before attacking South Korea. Despite the threats, foreign governments are struggling to assess how seriously to take North Korea's recent torrent of rhetoric, as it expresses its anger over continuing U.S.-South Korea military maneuvers just across the border. The centennial of Kim Il-sung's birthday is being marked by a lack of big parades in Pyongyang, and North Koreans are being encouraged to use the day to catch up with friends and family.
justice_department_219: The Associated Press (AP) is demanding answers from the Obama administration over its decision to subpoena two months of AP phone records. The subpoena was issued by the U.S. Department of Justice and includes records of calls from several AP bureaus and the personal phone lines of several staffers. The AP says the subpoena is a violation of its constitutional rights and calls it an unprecedented intrusion into its reporting. The Justice Department has not disclosed why it issued the subpoena, but it has said it is investigating leaks of sensitive information that potentially put the American people at risk. Attorney General Eric Holder recused himself from the case, leaving Deputy Attorney General James Cole to handle the investigation. The AP is calling on Holder to explain why the subpoena was issued and to take steps to protect journalistic rights.
us_senate_160: Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid has threatened to use the "nuclear option" to push through Obama appointees, which would eliminate filibusters for executive-branch nominations. This would bring the Senate back to a simple majority vote. This threat was made after months of Republican stalling tactics to block Obama's nominees.
middle_east_331: On Tuesday, a three-day humanitarian cease-fire began between Israel and Hamas in the Gaza Strip. The Egyptian-brokered truce aims to provide a temporary respite from fighting to allow for talks to begin anew. The cease-fire has been met with mixed reactions from both sides, as well as from the international community. For many Gazans, the break in violence has brought a sense of relief, allowing them to return to their neighborhoods and check on abandoned homes. However, for Israel, where more than 2,300 rockets have landed since early July, the absence of sirens blaring is a rare moment of peace. Despite the fragility of the cease-fire, some hope that it marks a turning point in the conflict.
federal_budget_245: 2014-02-07 The House passed a bipartisan budget deal on Thursday with easy approval, in a move that may ease the threat of a government shutdown for two years. The agreement struck by House Budget Chairman Paul Ryan and Senate Budget Committee Chairwoman Patty Murray sets government spending at $ 1.012 trillion for the current fiscal year and $ 1.014 trillion for next year. It would eliminate $ 45 billion from the next round of largely unpopular forced federal spending cuts - known as sequestration - that are set to hit in January and another $ 18 billion scheduled for 2015, resulting in a deficit reduction of more than $ 20 billion once the money spared from sequestration is factored in.
elections_511: In a stunning upset, Andrew Gillum won the Democratic nomination for Florida governor, defeating better-funded white, centrist candidates. This marks a departure from previous white, centrist nominees who have lost. His campaign focused on progressive policies such as expanding government-run healthcare, higher wages for workers, and Trump’s impeachment. ‘Monkey this up’: Republican Ron DeSantis’ controversial comments about Gillum’s win in the Republican primary have drawn criticism for their racial undertones. DeSantis, a staunch Trump supporter who won with Trump’s endorsement, said he did not want Florida voters to “monkey this up” by electing Gillum, a black mayor of Tallahassee. Gillum, in turn, called DeSantis’ comments racist and said Trump was using them to divide voters.
europe_110: Greece voted overwhelmingly to reject the latest bailout offer from the European Union, indicating its leaders' growing frustration with the punishing austerity measures that have been imposed on the country. The vote sets up a potential clash with the EU and the International Monetary Fund, which have provided Greece with hundreds of billions of euros in bailout loans. As Greece struggles to implement the austerity measures demanded by its creditors, it risks further damaging its already fragile economy.
world_779: The United States and the European Union announced new sanctions against Russia on Monday and Tuesday, targeting Russian officials, including President Putin's inner circle, and companies linked to him. The Obama administration said it was taking these actions because Russia has not lived up to its commitments under a recent diplomatic deal and has further escalated the crisis in Ukraine. The White House is targeting specific individuals and companies in order to pressure Putin to change his behavior and resolve the crisis peacefully. The European Union is also expected to add about 15 new targets to its Russia sanctions list on Monday. The US and the EU have been working closely together to coordinate their actions and present a unified front.
justice_department_263: Attorney General William Barr has been centralizing control over the Justice Department and taking blatant steps to protect President Donald Trump’s interests. The most recent example of this is the sentencing recommendation for Roger Stone, a longtime Trump advisor, which has been revised downward. Four career prosecutors resigned over the matter, and one resigned from the Justice Department altogether. The decision to revise the sentence recommendation came after Trump tweeted his dismay over the original recommendation, which had been made by the four prosecutors. The U.S. Department of Justice is an independent agency within the executive branch, but it has increasingly launched probes into the president’s opponents and softened penalties for his allies. The events of this week are raising pointed questions about the rule of law and the political independence of America’s largest law enforcement agency.
elections_234: obama has a slight lead over Romney in the polls, but the gap is closing fast as the election day approaches. battleground states such as Florida, Ohio, and Virginia are the crucial factors that will determine the outcome of the election. Romney has also been making a last-minute push in Ohio, which is considered to be a battleground state that could either go for Obama or Romney. the polls show that the election is too close to call, and the hurricane that hit the east coast has also had an impact on the election.
supreme_court_736: Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Chuck Grassley has announced that the committee will vote on the confirmation of Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh on Thursday, despite mounting pressure to delay the vote in light of new allegations of sexual assault. The woman accusing Kavanaugh, Christine Blasey Ford, has come forward publicly with a detailed account of the alleged assault, which took place at a party when she was 15 and Kavanaugh was 17. Ford claims that Kavanaugh held her down and tried to remove her clothes while covering her mouth with his hand and leading her to believe that he could "inadvertently kill me." Kavanaugh has denied the allegations.
terrorism_433: The story of the September 11 attacks on the U.S. embassy in Libya is still being investigated, but Republicans are using the hearing to question the actions of Hillary Clinton, who was Secretary of State at the time of the attack. The hearings have brought up conflicting accounts about what happened in Benghazi and who was responsible for the attack. The Republicans are using this to justify their political attacks on Clinton, while the Democrats are defending her actions and criticizing the Republicans for using the hearing for political gain. The investigation is ongoing, but it is unlikely that the Republicans will be able to prove that Clinton was directly responsible for the attack.
fbi_395: The former acting director of the FBI, Andrew McCabe, was fired by Attorney General Jeff Sessions on Friday night. McCabe was fired after multiple federal probes and reports showed that he lied to investigators while reviewing the bureau's probe into Hillary Clinton's use of a private email server. McCabe had previously been a confidant of former FBI Director James Comey, who was fired by President Trump in May 2017. McCabe's dismissal was two days before he would have been eligible for a lifetime pension.
israel_714: President Obama visited Israel on Wednesday, his first visit since taking office, and reaffirmed the United States’ commitment to the country and its security. During his stay, Obama spoke with President Shimon Peres, who said he believes Obama is prepared to take military action against Iran if necessary to prevent it from getting a nuclear weapon. Obama also met with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and urged him to give diplomacy more time to resolve the nuclear issue with Iran, but also told him that all options remain on the table if necessary. Obama’s visit to Israel was seen as a way to repair his strained relationship with Netanyahu, and to strengthen his image as a strong leader in the face of criticism from Israel’s right-wing government on issues such as settlement building.
gun_control_and_gun_rights_648: The NRA held its annual meeting in Houston, Texas, where the recent gun control debate was a central theme. NRA leaders warned that President Barack Obama and gun control advocates will stop at nothing to curtail their rights. The group is "in the midst of a once in a generation fight for everything we care about," according to NRA Executive Vice President Wayne LaPierre. The defeat of a bipartisan gun control measure in the Senate was celebrated by the NRA, but Sen. Dick Durbin of Illinois hopes that the "political sentiment" will change in the upper chamber so that legislation can be brought up again. The NRA leaders lashed out at members of the media and "political elites" during a Friday speech.
middle_east_351: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee began the process of approving a resolution that would grant President Obama authority to use force against Syria. The resolution is expected to be put to a committee vote Wednesday. The committee has already drafted the bill, and it contains language that limits the use of military force to a 60-day time frame and prohibits American troops from being deployed on the ground. The United Nations has called on countries to avoid further militarization of the conflict in Syria.
terrorism_499: The Boston Marathon bombing suspect, Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, is in serious condition at a hospital following his capture Friday night. The second suspect in the bombings, a brother of Tsarnaev, was killed in a shootout with police. The capture of Tsarnaev ended a tense, week-long manhunt that had paralyzed the city of Boston. Tsarnaev, who is from Chechnya and has been in the United States for less than two years, was identified by authorities on Friday. The manhunt began on April 15, when two bombs exploded near the finish line of the Boston Marathon, killing three people and injuring more than 170 others.
nsa_266: The NSA director, Gen. Keith Alexander, defended the agency's surveillance programs as a way to prevent terrorist attacks, saying that the two main programs, one that tracks foreigners' communications and another that gathers data from American phone and internet providers, work together to keep Americans safe. He also said that the NSA has deleted records of Americans' calls after five years. Meanwhile, the House Intelligence Committee chairman, Rep. Mike Rogers, said he was concerned that Snowden's flight to Hong Kong could be an attempt to seek asylum in China, and he said he was confident that the NSA would take steps to protect American interests.
impeachment_573: The House of Representatives voted Wednesday to impeach President Trump, making him the third president in U.S. history to be faced with high crimes and misdemeanors. The vote was split largely along party lines, with Democrats accusing Trump of abusing his power and obstructing Congress. Every Republican voted against both articles. The vote came after months of investigation into Trump's dealings with Ukraine and his request for political favors. The impeachment trial is expected to take place in the Senate early next year.
politics_745: Virginia’s Lt. Gov. Justin Fairfax is accused of sexual assault by two women, and his political allies are calling for him to resign. The Democratic Party of Virginia and other key Democrats have also called for his resignation. However, Fairfax has denied the allegations and is calling for an investigation. If impeachment proceedings begin, Virginia’s Democratic legislature could remove Fairfax from office, but it is unclear whether they will pursue that course of action.
us_senate_682: In an emotional speech on the Senate floor on Thursday, Minnesota Democrat Al Franken announced he would resign from the Senate following allegations of sexual misconduct by multiple women. Franken apologized for his behavior, but denied some of the allegations and said he remembered others differently. He also criticized President Trump for his treatment of women and said he was disappointed in the party for pressuring him to resign. Franken had been seen as a rising star in the Democratic Party and had been a leading voice on progressive issues.
north_korea_156: North Korea’s latest missile test failed upon launch on April 1, 2017. The type of missile is still being assessed, but officials say it is medium-range rather than a nuclear test. The test was a reminder of the risks faced by U.S. and South Korean service members. Vice President Pence arrived in South Korea on April 2 and called the test a “provocation.” The test occurred on the Day of the Sun, a North Korean holiday, but it is unclear if it was intentionally timed for the occasion. The North is known to be developing long-range ballistic missiles, and it is unclear if this latest test is part of that program. The United States has said that it will take a tougher stance against North Korea if China does not do more to pressure the regime. The United States has also said that it will not negotiate with North Korea until it stops its nuclear weapons program.
fiscal_cliff_842: The latest update on the fiscal cliff talks is that House Republicans are launching a parallel strategy to avert the fiscal cliff, seeking to pass a bill that would hike tax rates on income over $ 1 million, while extending rates on the rest of Americans. The legislation has already been declared dead on arrival by Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid and the White House. President Obama and House Speaker John Boehner are within reach of a deal, as the lawmakers appear to have scaled the walls of ideology, but the GOP fallback plan will jump-start negotiations again. The White House stated that the president will work with Congress to find a bipartisan solution that averts the fiscal cliff, protects the middle class, helps the economy and puts the nation on a fiscally sustainable path.
elections_68: The Super Tuesday primaries are over, and the frontrunners in the Democratic and Republican presidential races, Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump, won in their respective parties. While the Republican race has narrowed down to Trump and Sen. Marco Rubio, the Democratic race is still wide open, with Clinton, Sen. Bernie Sanders and former Vice President Joe Biden still in the running. In Super Tuesday, 12 states voted, with Texas being the most important prize. Overall, Super Tuesday was a big win for the Republicans, with Trump winning three of the four states he contested, and Rubio winning Minnesota. The Democrats, on the other hand, did not perform as well, with Clinton winning only two of the four states she contested, while Sanders won his home state of Vermont.
elections_585: Romney's campaign criticized the Obama administration on Tuesday for a first response to Tuesday's attacks that he said was an apology to the attackers, rather than condemning the attacks themselves. His criticism was based on a statement the administration released after the attacks on the embassy in Cairo that condemned efforts to offend the religious beliefs of Muslims, which he said was an apology for past U.S. behavior. The Obama campaign responded by accusing Romney of injecting politics into a matter of national security and of playing politics at a time of deadly violence. The criticism of Romney's comments was bipartisan, with Democrats and Republicans alike condemning the politics of the situation.
elections_561: In the first primary of the 2016 presidential campaign, Bernie Sanders has won the Democratic primary in New Hampshire by a landslide, beating Hillary Clinton by 22 percentage points, the biggest margin in a contested New Hampshire Democratic primary in decades. The victory was also a blowout for Sanders, with him winning 60 percent of the vote, while Clinton got 38 percent. The win has raised Sanders's profile and could give him momentum to pose a serious threat to Clinton in the Democratic primary.
elections_544: The 2020 Democratic presidential race is in full swing as six states hold primaries on Tuesday, March 10th. The most important state to watch is Michigan, which played a significant role in Bernie Sanders' 2016 victory. Sanders is hoping to replicate that victory, but polls suggest that former Vice President Joe Biden is leading him in Michigan and has a commanding lead in the delegate count. Biden has also been winning over key endorsements, including those from Senators Kamala Harris and Cory Booker, who have recently endorsed him. If Biden wins in Michigan, he will likely be able to secure the Democratic nomination.
elections_851: The Republican Party is grappling with its support for Roy Moore, the nominee for a Senate seat in Alabama, who has been accused of pursuing sexual relationships with teenage girls when he was in his 30s. On Monday, President Donald Trump endorsed Moore, saying that Democrats would hurt the party’s agenda if they won the seat. Trump also called on Moore to “go get ‘em,” and urged Republicans to rally around the candidate. This endorsement marks a significant shift in the party’s stance on Moore, and comes after Republican leaders had condemned him and called for him to step aside. Despite this, Moore has continued to refuse to withdraw from the race, and now has the support of the Republican Party.
national_security_81: The Mueller report, which was released by Attorney General William Barr on Thursday, has been met with mixed reactions. While President Trump and his allies are celebrating the lack of collusion with Russia, Democrats are expressing disappointment. The report does not say that Trump committed obstruction of justice, but it also does not exonerate him. The report finds that the Russian government attempted to influence the 2016 election, but it did not find evidence of collusion with the Trump campaign. The report also details efforts by the Russian military to hack into computers and steal documents from the Democratic National Committee and Clinton campaign. Overall, the Mueller report does not provide a definitive conclusion on whether Trump obstructed justice or colluded with Russia.
elections_198: The Republican National Convention is set to begin in Florida, but the Obama campaign is not standing idly by. The Obama campaign's schedule includes speeches by surrogates in battleground states, a tour of swing states, and a speech by First Lady Michelle Obama on "The Late Show with David Letterman." Meanwhile, Vice President Joe Biden will speak in Tampa, but he won't be the only Democrat in the city. The Democratic National Convention is also set to take place in Charlotte, North Carolina, next week.
national_security_702: Special counsel Robert Mueller did not find that the Trump campaign “ conspired or coordinated” with Russia to meddle in the 2016 elections, according to a summary by Attorney General William Barr. Mueller did not conclude that President Donald Trump obstructed justice, but Barr says the evidence is not sufficient to establish Trump committed an obstruction-of-justice offense. Barr’s summary leaves a few questions unresolved, and Democrats have already begun calling for the release of the full Mueller report. Trump and his allies are celebrating the summary as exoneration, but Democrats are demanding that Barr bring the full report before Congress.
impeachment_846: The House of Representatives has voted to send two formal charges of abuse of power and obstruction of Congress against President Donald Trump to the Senate. Trump has vowed to fight the charges and has suggested he wants to see the trial move quickly, but most Republicans have expressed support for a speedy trial without witnesses. The Senate trial is expected to begin next week and may last for only a few days. It is unclear how the trial will proceed or what evidence will be presented.
immigration_675: President Trump has moved to end asylum protections for most Central American migrants crossing the U.S. southern border. Migrants who pass through another country first will be ineligible for asylum at the U.S. southern border. There are exceptions, such as if someone has been trafficked or if the country the migrant passed through did not sign one of the major international treaties that govern how refugees are managed. The new rule will apply to initial asylum screening and will increase the burden on poorly equipped countries to process asylum claims. The American Civil Liberties Union has called the new rule "patently unlawful" and vowed to file a lawsuit against it. The Trump administration has overreached its authority and violated the law, according to House Speaker Nancy Pelosi. The proposed changes represent the latest effort by the Trump administration to crack down on immigration.
disaster_269: President Trump waived a 99-year-old shipping law, the Jones Act, in order to help Puerto Rico recover from Hurricane Maria. The waiver temporarily lifted restrictions prohibiting foreign-flagged vessels from carrying fuel and other emergency supplies between U.S. ports. Trump made the decision after an outcry from Congress about shortages of fuel, food, and emergency supplies on the island. The waiver is in effect for 10 days and covers all products. The decision was made at the request of Puerto Rico's governor and in consultation with the Defense Department.
gun_control_and_gun_rights_241: The Senate on Thursday ended a Republican filibuster on a new gun control bill, clearing the way for debate to begin on a hugely emotional issue. At least 16 Republicans crossed the aisle to consider the gun legislation, but the vote was only the opening move in what could be a drawn-out floor fight that will center on a deal unveiled Wednesday by Sens. Pat Toomey ( R-Pa. ) , Mark Kirk ( R-Ill. ) and Joe Manchin ( D-W.Va. ) that would require background checks on all commercial gun sales and end the so-called “gun show loophole .” President Barack Obama spoke by phone with family members after the vote, congratulating them on the progress and reiterating that much work remains.
fbi_167: The new report from the Justice Department's Inspector General Michael Horowitz has revealed multiple errors made by the FBI during its investigation into a Trump campaign official. The report cleared the bureau of political bias but did not exonerate it entirely. Some of the errors were due to a lack of resources, while others were a result of poor management. The report also found that the FBI made "fundamental errors" in its surveillance of Trump campaign adviser Carter Page. The report's release has sparked a wider investigation into the bureau's conduct, with U.S. Attorney John Durham pushing back on some of the report's conclusions.
us_house_518: House Speaker John Boehner has announced the creation of a special committee to investigate the 2012 attacks in Benghazi, Libya. The committee will be led by South Carolina Republican Trey Gowdy and will have a 7-5 split between Republicans and Democrats. Boehner said the committee will have the power to issue subpoenas and will go until it has the answers to questions about the run-up to the attack, the administration's handling of the attack, and the White House's effort to shape public perception of the attack afterward. Democrats have objected to the committee's makeup and powers, and White House press secretary Jay Carney has hinted that the administration will not cooperate with the investigation.
elections_174: Bernie Sanders ended his campaign for president on Wednesday, citing a lack of viability. This decision comes after a string of primary losses and the fact that 2020 was not his year. Sanders was a progressive socialist who ran an unconventional campaign, but his message resonated with many. He faced criticism for his old-school socialist views and lack of support from the establishment. Despite his loss, Sanders is still on the ballot and will continue to collect delegates. Many Sanders supporters are sad but will ultimately vote for Joe Biden.
politics_86: The release of more than 2,800 documents related to the assassination of President John F. Kennedy in 1963 has sparked new interest in the case. One of the first interesting documents to be unearthed was a memo written by J Edgar Hoover that said the FBI had a warning from a Dallas police officer about a potential death threat to Lee Harvey Oswald, who was in police custody. Other documents reveal that the CIA warned Britain of a possible assassination attempt on Prime Minister Winston Churchill in 1940. The release of the documents has added to the raft of conspiracy theories surrounding the assassination.
elections_487: Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders clashed over their views on the economy, healthcare, and foreign policy during a fifth Democratic presidential debate in New Hampshire on Thursday night. The two candidates had a heated exchange over who is the most progressive, with Clinton accusing Sanders of judging her unfairly and Sanders defending his voting record on gun control legislation. The debate also touched on the ongoing controversy over Sanders’ comments about Clinton being a moderate, with Sanders reiterating his support for her but expressing disappointment at the way she has been treated by the media and some Democratic leaders. Overall, the debate highlighted the sharp differences between the two candidates and the ongoing battle for the soul of the Democratic Party.
elections_778: Sanders and Clinton are continuing their heated battle for the Democratic nomination, with Sanders attacking Clinton's qualifications and Clinton dismissing his concerns. Sanders said he doesn't believe Clinton is qualified if she takes money from special interest groups, supports disastrous trade agreements, and voted for the Iraq war. Clinton's campaign spokesman denied that Sanders said Clinton was not qualified and accused him of taking things too far. The controversy continued as Sanders and Clinton campaigned in New York, with Sanders joining Harry Belafonte and Erica Garner at the Apollo Theater to connect with African-American voters.
healthcare_841: A federal judge in Texas has struck down the Affordable Care Act (ACA) of President Barack Obama, ruling that the individual mandate to have health insurance is unconstitutional. This decision, which is being appealed, means that the ACA, also known as Obamacare, is no longer valid. The ruling has immediate practical impact on the ACA because the mandate is a central component of the law, but it does not affect the health insurance coverage that people have already purchased. The ruling has sparked political debate about the future of healthcare in the United States, with Democrats and Republicans expressing different views about the decision.
impeachment_415: The House Judiciary Committee has told a federal appeals court that it is still seeking testimony from former White House counsel Don McGahn because he could provide information that would help the panel decide whether to recommend additional articles of impeachment against President Donald Trump. The committee submitted a brief to the D.C. Circuit Court of Appeals arguing that its subpoena of McGahn is not moot following the House's vote to impeach Trump on two charges related to his interactions with Ukraine rather than on actions uncovered during Mueller's Russia probe.
middle_east_217: The Obama administration announced on Thursday that the United States was sending military and political aid to the Syrian opposition, in response to the regime’s use of chemical weapons against rebels. The decision was reportedly driven by a combination of factors, including the realization that Assad was gaining a permanent advantage over rebel groups, the fear of imminent sectarian bloodshed spilling into neighboring countries, and the discovery that Assad had used sarin gas against rebels. The administration is reportedly planning to provide small arms, ammunition, and possibly anti-tank weapons to the rebels, and is also considering imposing a no-fly zone to protect civilians from regime attacks. The decision was met with mixed reactions, with some experts calling it a positive step towards resolving the conflict, while others expressed concerns about the potential for the aid to fall into the wrong hands and exacerbate the violence.
justice_department_388: William Barr, former U.S. Attorney General, has been under attack from liberal politicians for his handling of the Roger Stone case. Some have called for his resignation or even impeachment. Barr has denied any political interference and has said he was surprised by the initial sentencing recommendation. The Justice Department has withdrawn its recommendation and the prosecutors in the case have resigned. Barr has also been criticized for his handling of the Flynn case and his decision to review the Mueller report. Despite these criticisms, Barr has maintained his loyalty to Trump and has not ruled out running for president in 2022.
impeachment_764: Pelosi Announces Articles of Impeachment Against Trump; House Judiciary Committee to Consider Them Tuesday House Speaker Nancy Pelosi on Tuesday announced two articles of impeachment against President Donald Trump, accusing him of abuse of power and obstruction of Congress. The committee plans to consider them at an unusual evening session Wednesday. The announcement comes after nearly two years of speculation about whether impeachment would be pursued. House Democrats said Trump’s actions were an “unacceptable violation of his oath of office.” House Votes to Send Impeachment Articles to Senate; McConnell Says He’ll Hold a Vote to Acquit Trump The House of Representatives on Wednesday evening voted to send the impeachment articles against President Donald Trump to the Senate, where Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell has announced he will hold a vote to acquit Trump. McConnell’s move marks the beginning of the Senate trial of Trump, which is expected to be a formality vote, with the Republican-majority Senate unlikely to vote to remove Trump from office.
environment_348: The Trump administration announced that the US will withdraw from the Paris climate agreement. This move is seen as a major setback in global efforts to combat climate change and has been met with criticism from environmental groups, world leaders, and even members of Trump’s own party. The US is the second largest emitter of greenhouse gases in the world and its withdrawal from the agreement is expected to make it harder to achieve global emissions reductions. The decision to withdraw has been described as “stunning,” “irreversible,” and “brutal.”
immigration_117: President Trump on Friday said that Republicans should stop wasting their time on immigration until after the midterm elections, dealing a setback to lawmakers who were looking to get his support. Trump has fumed over the lack of action on immigration and has blamed Democrats for the problem. The House rejected a hard-line immigration bill on Thursday, and Republican leaders delayed the vote on a separate, more moderate bill until next week. Trump signed an executive order on Wednesday permitting families to remain together after facing mounting political pressure.
national_defense_576: The assassination of Iranian Maj. Gen. Qasem Soleimani by US drone has had a ripple effect across the Middle East, with many leaders scrambling to prevent a conflict with Iran. Gulf countries, in particular, are worried about the fallout from the killing and are flying around the world to try and contain the damage. However, the US has not been forthcoming about its reasons for the assassination, which has only added to the confusion and uncertainty in the region. Many are also questioning the wisdom of the assassination, with some suggesting that it may have been a reckless move that could have serious consequences. As tensions continue to rise, it remains to be seen what the future holds for the region.
nsa_332: Edward Snowden, the former NSA contractor, has leaked highly classified information about the US government's surveillance programs. He has fled to Hong Kong, where he has been granted temporary asylum. The US government is reportedly considering criminal charges against Snowden, but the Chinese government has not given any indication of whether it will extradite him. The European Parliament is also expected to debate the spy programs, which have been criticized for violating local privacy protections. Snowden has reportedly told a Hong Kong newspaper that the NSA has hacked computers in Hong Kong and mainland China since 2009.
healthcare_307: House Republicans launched an all-out assault on Pres. Barack Obama’s signature health care reform law, holding a series of committee hearings and other events ahead of a planned vote Wednesday on repealing the measure. The repeal vote will be the latest House Republican attempt to undermine Obamacare, but the measure has no chance of passing the Senate, and the White House has made it clear that Obama would veto such a measure. Democrats accused Republicans of wasting time with political theater instead of focusing on helping the economy.
middle_east_271: The Iran nuclear talks neared their end, with negotiators from Iran and six world powers continuing to work toward a comprehensive deal. The talks in Lausanne, Switzerland, focused on issues such as the storage of nuclear fuel and the lifting of economic sanctions. While some issues remained unsettled, there were signs of progress, with officials from the U.S., Britain, France, China, Russia, Germany, and Iran agreeing to a framework for a deal. The agreement, if finalized, would limit Iran's nuclear program and commit it to "the most robust and intrusive inspections and transparency regime ever negotiated for any nuclear program in history." If a final agreement is reached, economic sanctions would be lifted and Iran would be allowed to enrich uranium.
state_department_784: The Trump administration has signaled a shift in its Syria policy with a focus on protecting civilians, rather than overthrowing Bashar Al-Assad. This change in policy has led to a renewed harmony with European allies and a warning against the use of chemical weapons. Secretary of State Rex Tillerson is currently visiting Moscow to meet with Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov. While Tillerson has advocated for a ceasefire in Syria, there are indications that Russia will continue to support the Assad regime. Tillerson's visit to Moscow is being closely watched as a test of his skills and the US-Russia relationship.
national_security_92: President Trump is in New York City for a week of meetings and speeches with foreign leaders amid global uncertainty about a nuclear North Korea . Trump's Monday will be packed with meetings, leading up to his first-ever speech to the General Assembly on Tuesday — a highly anticipated address in which the president is expected to discuss the specific threats of North Korea, Iran and global terrorism. The president's schedule also includes meeting with representatives from more than 120 nations, as well as U.N. Secretary General António Guterres, to discuss reforming the international organization. The Trump administration has not been shy about expressing its discontent with the U.N. The White House believes the U.S. pays too much for what it gets in return and that peacekeeping missions should be examined for excessive spending. Administration officials have described the U.N. as a bloated bureaucracy and have expressed anger by what they view as insufficient support for key allies, like Israel.
us_military_143: On Tuesday, pro-Iran militiamen stormed the gates of the U.S. Embassy in Baghdad, vandalizing the property and causing U.S. diplomats to hide in lockdown. The U.S. government condemned the attack and blamed Iran for it, and announced that it would send additional forces to protect the embassy. The embassy attack was the latest in a series of incidents involving pro-Iran militias in Iraq, and it raised tensions between the U.S. and Iran.
immigration_644: President Trump’s travel ban, originally targeting seven predominantly Muslim countries, is set to go into effect Thursday night. The Supreme Court granted the Trump administration’s request to reinstate part of the ban, which means foreign nationals from the six countries listed can enter the US if they have a credible claim of a bona fide relationship with someone or something in the US. The administration has provided guidance on what qualifies as a bona fide relationship, which includes parents, spouses, children, adult sons or daughters, and siblings. However, grandparents, grandchildren, aunts, uncles, nieces, nephews, cousins, brothers-in-law, and sisters-in-law are not considered close family. The Supreme Court also lifted the stay on the ban, allowing it to take effect while the justices consider its constitutionality.
immigration_207: President Obama has decided to issue an executive order on immigration, which will give deportation relief to roughly 5 million illegal immigrants. Republicans in Congress vehemently oppose Obama’s action, saying it will encourage more illegal immigrants to come to the U.S. There was a surge of illegal child immigrants earlier this year, in part due to the belief that they would not be returned to their homes in Central America. White House press secretary Josh Earnest tried to justify Obama’s pending executive action by saying that House Republicans have forced the president into this position by refusing to act on a Senate-passed bill. However, Obama had previously stated that a blanket waiver against deportations would be difficult to defend legally. The president’s move has been met with both praise and criticism from various groups and individuals. Some have praised Obama’s action as a necessary step towards immigration reform, while others have condemned it as an affront to the Constitution and outside of the law.
elections_649: The latest news as it happens: The Trump campaign is facing backlash from the Republican National Committee over the nominating process. The RNC chairman, Reince Priebus, criticized Trump for alleging the nominating process is "rigged" and urged him to "give us all a break." The dispute over process is building as Cruz's operation has proved more adroit lately in getting supporters elected as the actual delegates who will attend the convention. Last weekend at the Colorado state convention, Cruz gained all 34 delegates, while Trump won six of the 34 alternate spots. The campaign has insisted they can do this, and that Cruz won't get the opportunity to use his backup delegate allies on a second ballot. However, based on their own analysis, Cruz could pick up at least 130-170 additional delegate votes on the second ballot at an open convention, making it even harder for Trump to lock down the nomination.
federal_budget_550: The Obama administration is preparing to release its budget proposal, which is expected to include cuts to Social Security and Medicare programs. The administration has said that these cuts are necessary to reduce the federal deficit. However, House Speaker John Boehner has already rejected the proposed tax increases that would fund those cuts, stating that the president’s plan is “no way to lead and move the country forward”
white_house_205: The special counsel Robert Mueller found no evidence that President Trump or his aides conspired with Russia during the 2016 election. The attorney general William Barr summarized the findings of the investigation in a letter to Congress, which he transmitted on Sunday. Barr wrote that the evidence developed during the investigation was not sufficient to establish that the president committed an obstruction-of-justice offense. Trump, speaking to reporters in Florida, said the report was a total exoneration.
middle_east_183: Israel and Hamas reached a cease-fire agreement Wednesday, ending a week of deadly conflict in the Gaza Strip. The truce calls for an end to rocket fire from Gaza into Israel and Israeli airstrikes on Gaza, but it remains unclear when the border crossings will be fully opened for people and goods. The cease-fire came after a fragile two-day truce was violated when Israeli troops opened fire on Palestinians surging toward the border. The rockets and parts that came from Iran were conventional, but from one point of view, Israel was using the Gaza battle to learn the capabilities of Hamas and Iranian-backed Islamic Jihad, as well as to disrupt those links.
state_department_534: Hillary Clinton has agreed to turn over her private email server to federal investigators. The FBI has now obtained the server and has confirmed that two of Clinton's emails contained "top secret/SCI level" information, making it even more important that the FBI and the State Department secure these documents. The decision to give up the server came after the FBI said Clinton's lawyer was not permitted to possess the classified information contained in some of the emails. The Inspector General of the intelligence community, I. Charles McCullough III, has confirmed that two of Clinton's emails met the standard of "top secret/SCI level," while other messages are still being scrutinized to see how sensitive they should have been. The revelation that Clinton's private emails contained sensitive information derived from spy satellites and signal intelligence undercuts her defense that she had no reason to believe she was dealing with classified information.
healthcare_72: Republican lawmakers continue to criticize President Obama's controversial healthcare reform initiative, pouncing on a report that shows the low number of people who have signed up for the insurance exchanges set up by the law. The House is also expected to vote on a bill that would allow Americans to keep their health plans, which the president had promised they could do. Meanwhile, former President Bill Clinton has joined the ranks of Democrats who are openly calling on Obama to change course and keep people on their existing plans. The White House is reportedly considering a last-minute fix to the law, but it remains unclear what, if anything, it will do.
us_senate_12: Senate Democrats and Republicans are at a standoff over President Trump's Supreme Court nominee, Neil Gorsuch. Democrats plan to filibuster Gorsuch's confirmation, requiring a 60-vote threshold, while Republicans threaten to change Senate rules to eliminate the filibuster. Both sides are damaging the Senate and the institution of the Supreme Court. The filibuster is a symbolic act, but it will not stop Gorsuch's confirmation. The showdown highlights the growing partisanship in American politics, with both sides willing to destroy traditions and institutions to advance their goals.
elections_127: President Donald Trump and House Democrats are using “racists” and “socialists” as terms of attack against each other. Trump condemned four female, liberal Democratic congresswomen for their comments on various issues, while the Democrats condemned Trump for his “racist” comments. The House passed a resolution condemning Trump’s comments, while Trump continued to attack the group, resulting in chants of “send her back” by his supporters at a campaign rally in North Carolina. Trump also criticized the four freshmen congresswomen for supporting policies such as a Green New Deal and lowering health care costs, which he claimed would lead to socialism and a weak economy.
fbi_137: President Donald Trump has announced that he will nominate Christopher Wray, a former Justice Department official, to be the new director of the FBI. The announcement comes nearly one month after Trump fired FBI Director James Comey and just one day before Comey is scheduled to testify before the Senate intelligence committee. Trump called Wray "a man of impeccable credentials" in a tweet. During a visit to Cincinnati, Ohio, on Wednesday, Trump remarked briefly on his decision, telling the traveling press that Wray "will be great." Meanwhile, one by one, then-FBI Director James Comey pulled aside three of the bureau's top officials for private chats to discuss his Oval Office meeting with President Trump, during which Comey alleged that the president pressed him to shut down the federal criminal investigation of Trump's then-national security adviser, Michael Flynn. The White House and Trump have categorically denied Comey's account. It will be Trump's word versus the word of Comey and at least three other leaders of the FBI.
elections_509: Mitt Romney, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, faced a boisterous audience at the NAACP convention in Houston, Texas, where he was expected to talk about general economic issues. However, his attempt to engage black voters by mentioning his plans to repeal President Barack Obama's signature healthcare law, the Affordable Care Act, drew boos from the crowd. The booing was a result of the controversy surrounding the law and Romney's perceived insensitivity to the struggles of black Americans. Despite this, Romney continued with his message about the need for job creation and economic growth. The latest wave of attacks on Romney for his wealth and business practices, as well as his perceived insensitivity to the concerns of minority voters, has raised questions about his ability to win the support of key voting blocs.
justice_18: Rod Rosenstein, the No. 2 man at the Justice Department, faces an uncertain future after a chaotic day of conflicting reports. On Monday, Axios reported that he had resigned, while the White House denied that. Later, conflicting reports emerged about a meeting with White House Chief of Staff John Kelly, and whether Rosenstein was heading to the White House expecting to be fired. On Tuesday, the White House said Trump and Rosenstein will meet on Thursday. The Times reported last week that Rosenstein discussed secretly recording the president and invoking the 25th amendment to remove him from office.
cia_787: Summary: The Senate Intelligence Committee held a confirmation hearing for President Obama's nominee for CIA director, John Brennan, who has been Obama's counterterrorism adviser since 2009. During the hearing, Brennan was questioned about leaks of classified information to journalists, harsh interrogation methods, and the legality of targeted drone strikes against U.S. citizens linked to al-Qaeda. He defended the use of lethal force as a last resort and said that the United States does not conduct strikes "to punish terrorists for past transgressions." The committee will meet again in a classified setting on February 12.
us_senate_603: This week, the Republican-led Senate was poised to vote on its latest attempt to repeal the Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as Obamacare. However, after a meeting with his colleagues, Senate Republican leader John Cornyn (R-TX) announced that the vote would be delayed indefinitely. This setback comes as Republicans have been unable to muster the 50 votes necessary to pass their repeal bill. The latest version of the bill, sponsored by Lindsey Graham (R-SC) and Bill Cassidy (R-LA), would dismantle much of the ACA and shift funding to states. However, it faces opposition from key Republicans, including Sen. Susan Collins (R-ME), who has said she will vote against it. With the deadline for passing the bill through the Senate's budget reconciliation process quickly approaching, Republicans may be forced to abandon their repeal efforts.
elections_188: In a blistering attack on Donald Trump, Hillary Clinton has released a new ad that attempts to depict Trump as a racist, a candidate supported by white supremacists and the Ku Klux Klan. Clinton said Trump and Republicans are reinforcing harmful stereotypes, calling it a disturbing preview of the kind of president Trump would be. Trump said the allegations are the oldest ploy in the Democratic playbook, but Clinton is n’t backing down. In a speech in the swing state of Nevada, Clinton also tried to tie Trump to the so-called "AltRight" or "alternative right," a very vocal group whose nationalist beliefs push beyond mainstream conservatism.
federal_budget_336: The Senate is expected to pass a bipartisan budget deal this week. The agreement avoids a government shutdown scheduled for January 15 and allows for $ 1.014 trillion in spending for 2015. Nine Republicans joined Democrats in supporting the deal, while only one Republican Senator facing a primary challenge voted with Democrats. The budget deal is a rare example of bipartisanship in Congress. The two-year budget plan was agreed upon by House Budget Committee Chairman Paul Ryan and Senate Budget Committee Chairwoman Patty Murray last week. The deal was passed by the House on a 332-94 vote.
terrorism_490: On Tuesday, the Boston Police Department issued a high alert for a rental van that may have tried to gain entry to the finish line of the Boston Marathon. An interfaith service is scheduled in Boston on Thursday, where President Barack Obama will speak. The bombing victims have been identified. The third victim was an 8-year-old boy named Martin Richard. The FBI has video surveillance from a Lord & Taylor department store across the street from the second explosion of a man acting suspiciously, including dropping a bag and reacting to the first explosion. The person of interest is a young white male wearing a dark-colored jacket, a gray hooded sweatshirt, a white or off-white baseball cap on backwards, and carrying a backpack. The FBI is asking for the public's help in identifying the person. The FBI is also looking for a second person seen in the video. The FBI is conducting a thorough investigation into the bombing, which has caused chaos and disrupted the city.
mexico_658: President Donald Trump has threatened to impose tariffs on Mexican imports starting in June unless the Mexican government curbs migration to the US.
