Some Democrats are calling for a delay in the confirmation process until an FBI investigation is completed, while Republicans are insisting that the hearing go forward. The Senate has the power to approve or reject Kavanaugh's nomination, but the confirmation process is expected to be contentious.
coronavirus_652: Trump has unveiled a roadmap for states to loosen social distancing guidelines as the nation grapples with the coronavirus pandemic. The guidelines, which he said are designed to help states reopen, will be nonbinding, leaving it to governors to decide when and how to implement them. Trump has faced criticism for his handling of the pandemic and has lashed out at Democratic governors who have imposed strict stay-at-home orders. He has also encouraged supporters to "liberate" states that have experienced protests over the lockdowns. Despite his claims of "absolute authority," Trump has acknowledged that the ultimate decisions about reopening will be made by governors.
white_house_231: President Obama recently announced that U.N. Ambassador Susan Rice has withdrawn her name for Secretary of State. Rice was the front-runner for the position but faced criticism over her remarks about the terrorist attacks in Libya in 2012. The withdrawal of her nomination was widely seen as a way to avoid a contentious confirmation hearing. Critics accused Rice of misleading the public and claimed that her comments about the attacks were based on false information. Obama defended Rice's comments as necessary in the immediate aftermath of the attacks. However, the controversy surrounding Rice's nomination was seen as an opportunity for Republicans to attack the administration on other issues.
sexual_misconduct_873: Former Vice President Joe Biden has been accused of sexually assaulting a woman in the 1990s when he was a senator. The woman, Tara Reade, has said that Biden forced her against the wall and penetrated her with his fingers in the spring of 1993. Biden has denied the allegations and called on the Senate to release any records related to Reade's complaint. Reade has said that she filed a limited report with the congressional personnel office at the time but did not detail the allegations against Biden. The AP has discovered additional transcripts and notes from interviews with Reade in which she said she did not use the phrase "sexual harassment" in the report.
lgbt_rights_800: A pair of landmark cases, Hollingsworth v. Perry and the Defense of Marriage Act, has landed before the Supreme Court in what could be a momentous week for the nation's highest court. The California case challenges Proposition 8, a voter-passed ban on same-sex marriage that has already been overturned by the state Supreme Court. The Defense of Marriage Act, or DOMA, is a federal law that denies federal benefits to married same-sex couples. The two cases represent the opposing viewpoints on the legality of same-sex marriage, with opponents of same-sex marriage arguing that the traditional definition of marriage must be upheld, while proponents argue that same-sex couples should have equal rights. The justices are expected to deliver a landmark ruling on the issue.
elections_863: The Iowa caucus results are still being tallied, but a messy process has raised questions about the accuracy of the vote count. The Iowa Democratic Party has not declared a winner yet, despite all precincts reporting. The app used to record the votes had issues and there are inconsistencies in the results. There are calls for a recanvass of the results, but the party has not yet said if it will comply. The Republicans seem to be relatively unaffected by the chaos in Iowa, with President Trump declaring victory in the state and former Mayor Pete Buttigieg holding a narrow lead over Sen. Bernie Sanders.
elections_634: Mitt Romney has a clear-eyed view of his chances in the final debate Monday night at Lynn University in Boca Raton, Florida. He believes it will be difficult to win, since the debate is focused exclusively on foreign policy, a strength for President Barack Obama. However, Romney’s top advisers say that even if he doesn’t bring his A game, Obama is slightly better positioned in the states that will dictate the outcome. The debate will be the last chance for Romney to make a difference in the election.
supreme_court_401: The Senate Judiciary Committee is holding a historic confirmation hearing for Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh over a two-day period. Kavanaugh is Donald Trump's second nominee, and his hearing is being used by Democrats to put up a strong resistance to Trump's conservative agenda. Kavanaugh has been accused of assaulting a woman named Christine Blasey Ford, which he has denied. He is also being scrutinized for his views on hot-button issues such as abortion, racial justice, and gun control. Despite facing tough questioning, Kavanaugh's confirmation seems likely, as Republicans hold a slim majority in the Senate.
impeachment_540: The Senate has adopted the rules for President Trump’s impeachment trial. The Republicans and Democrats clashed over the rules, with the Democrats demanding more evidence and witnesses. The Republican-led Senate rejected Democratic demands and the rules package was passed in a party-line vote. The back-and-forth at trial over calling witnesses followed weeks of Democrats demanding more evidence for the upper chamber’s hearing. Majority Leader Mitch McConnell of Kentucky and his Republican conference were united about following the same procedures used for President Bill Clinton’s impeachment trial in 1999. The rules resolution adopted gives each side 24 hours over three days, the same timeline used in Mr. Clinton’s trial.
lgbt_rights_4: Rowan County Clerk Kim Davis, who refused to issue same-sex marriage licenses to couples, was ordered to jail by a federal judge for her defiance. This sparked a national debate on religious freedom and same-sex marriage. The fight over same-sex marriage continues, as several other clerks and judges have also refused to issue licenses. The controversy has led to a rise in support for Davis and other conservative politicians. The legal battle is likely to continue, and the issue of religious freedom and same-sex marriage remains a contentious topic.
world_323: Opposition leaders signed a deal with Ukraine's president on Friday to defuse a political crisis that has left scores dead and hundreds injured. The agreement calls for early elections, a new constitution and a new unity government. Ukrainian authorities will now name a new government -- including opposition figures -- within 10 days and will refrain from violence. The Ukrainian parliament approved an amnesty for protesters involved in the violent months-long standoff. The President of Ukraine has fired his military chief after 26 people were killed during clashes with protesters.
elections_623: Two top elections in Florida are heading for recounts after an incredibly close race. The governor’s race between Republican Gov. Rick Scott and incumbent Democrat Bill Nelson has narrowed to 12,500 votes, and the Senate race between Republican U.S. Rep. Ron DeSantis and Democratic mayor Andrew Gillum has narrowed to 33,000 votes. President Donald Trump has weighed in on the matter, calling the potential for a recount a “fraud” and referring to one of Nelson’s attorneys. The Republican Party has filed lawsuits in Broward and Palm Beach counties, accusing election officials of “incompetence and gross mismanagement.” Florida law requires a machine recount when the leading candidate’s margin is 0.5 percentage points or less, and a hand recount is ordered if the machine recount shows a difference of less than 0.25 percentage points. The recount is expected to be completed by Thursday.
polarization_819: President Donald Trump condemned political violence on Wednesday after multiple suspicious packages were sent to Democratic leaders and CNN. The packages contained pipe bombs and white powder. The FBI is investigating the incidents, and no one has been hurt yet. The packages were addressed to Hillary Clinton, Barack Obama, and CNN's Manhattan office. The FBI has also intercepted a package addressed to former Vice President Joe Biden and another in Los Angeles. Trump has been criticized for his rhetoric on the media and political opponents. The president has not been charged with any crimes related to the packages.
middle_east_824: The Iranian nuclear deal, struck on Sunday, aims to buy time and build trust for a permanent agreement. The deal allows Iran to continue enriching uranium, a first step towards a nuclear bomb, and suspends certain parts of its nuclear program. It also lifts some sanctions on Iran, which has been struggling with a failing economy due to the sanctions. The deal is controversial, as some see it as a victory for Iran, while others believe it is too close to a nuclear breakthrough. The deal does not address Iran's role in the Syrian civil war and other regional conflicts.
elections_149: Mitt Romney faced criticism Monday after a video surfaced of a private fundraiser in May during which he said nearly half of Americans would vote for President Obama no matter what. In a hastily called news conference, Romney defended his remarks, saying he was speaking off the cuff in response to a question. He said he wanted to create jobs so that more Americans could pay taxes. However, the video has raised questions about Romney's empathy and ability to connect with the middle class. Meanwhile, Romney's campaign released a new ad attacking the president on foreign policy. The ad criticizes the Obama administration for failing to lead in the Middle East and for being weak on Iran.
elections_325: Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump are preparing for their first presidential debate on Monday night. While Clinton has a clear lead in most national polls, Trump has closed the gap in recent weeks. The expectations for the debate are high, with millions of viewers expected to tune in. Clinton hopes to show her authenticity and human side during the debate, while Trump aims to prove that he is a reasonable person with a solid grasp of the issues. The general consensus is that Trump needs to remain calm and respectful, while Clinton needs to cut through the pre-tested and polled responses.
world_347: Nelson Mandela died at the age of 95. He was the first black president of South Africa and spent nearly 30 years in prison for his anti-apartheid activism. He was a global cause celebre during the long apartheid years and inspired millions around the world. Mandela helped end apartheid and spent time in prison for his actions. He was a charismatic leader and inspired many people around the world to fight for equality. Mandela was known for his strength of character and was a potent leader and example for humanity.
elections_522: In his keynote address at the Republican National Convention , New Jersey Governor Chris Christie attacked President Barack Obama for absentee leadership and called on Republicans to lead a “ new era of truth-telling .” Christie praised Mitt Romney and Paul Ryan for their plans to revive the economy and reduce the size of government. Meanwhile, fact-checkers found that Romney made several false or misleading claims in his speech, including that President Obama began his term in office with an apology tour. At the convention, Vice Presidential nominee Paul Ryan gave a powerful speech that repeatedly brought delegates to their feet, ripping apart President Obama’s economic policies and defending the Republicans’ plans for Medicare reform.
elections_333: The storm over Donald Trump’s continued attacks on the family of fallen soldier Capt. Humayun Khan has reached a boiling point. Senators John McCain and Lindsey Graham have joined the growing number of Republicans condemning Trump’s behavior. McCain issued a lengthy statement on Monday, calling Trump’s comments about the Khan family “disparaging” and “disrespectful.” Graham said Trump has “disqualified himself” from being president. Meanwhile, the Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton has used Trump’s comments to her advantage, calling his behavior “disgusting” and arguing that it shows “he’s not fit to be president.” The Republican National Committee has also distanced itself from Trump’s comments, while the GOP vice presidential nominee Mike Pence has released a statement saying that the Khan family deserves “honor and gratitude.”
gun_control_and_gun_rights_414: Obama and many legislators have called for action on gun control after the Sandy Hook school shooting. This includes a call for an assault weapons ban and restrictions on high-capacity magazines. Pro-gun organizations and politicians have been mostly silent so far, but some conservative bloggers have reminded readers of instances in which legal gun carriers have thwarted gunmen. The president and lawmakers are discussing specific policy proposals, but no concrete action has been taken yet. The latest information on the shooting is that the shooter was armed with a high-powered rifle, two handguns, and hundreds of rounds of ammunition. The death toll from the shooting is 27, including 20 children.
europe_273: Scotland's historic decision to remain part of the United Kingdom has been celebrated by voters and politicians alike. With an 85% turnout, 55.3% of voters chose to stay with the UK, while 44.7% voted for independence. This vote has relieved investors and markets across the world, who had feared an independent Scotland could cause economic havoc. The decision has also led to a re-evaluation of the UK's relationship with Europe, with concerns of a future Brexit being less likely. The vote has been widely praised as a positive step for the future of the UK and its relationship with other countries.
federal_budget_628: The government shutdown began in a stalemate over spending, and despite weeks of talking past each other, congressional leaders and President Barack Obama met Wednesday evening to try to find a way out of the crisis. However, neither side discussed any potential compromises, and the meeting was described as "unproductive" by Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell. The parties are on the verge of another crisis, over whether to raise the debt ceiling by Oct. 17, at which point the federal government won't be able to pay its bills.
violence_in_america_654: The St. Louis County grand jury on Monday decided not to indict Darren Wilson, a white police officer in Ferguson, Missouri, for the shooting death of an unarmed black teenager, Michael Brown. The decision came after more than 70 hours of testimony from roughly 60 witnesses over 25 days. Protests erupted in Ferguson and St. Louis after the announcement, with some looting and rioting. The grand jury's decision has sparked a national debate about race, police brutality, and gun control.
terrorism_520: Summary: The Obama administration has announced that Boston Marathon bombing suspect Dzhokhar Tsarnaev will not be treated as an enemy combatant, and will instead go through the civilian court system. This decision has been met with criticism from some Republican lawmakers who wanted the administration to consider the option for the sake of intelligence gathering. The suspect was captured Friday night and is currently in serious condition in the hospital. Authorities are trying to pinpoint the motives behind the attacks and are also trying to determine if there are any other bombs or weapons caches out there. Some Republican congressmen have called for a focus on threats from within the Muslim community.
us_senate_40: The Senate passed the Republican-backed $ 1.5 trillion tax-cut bill, giving President Donald Trump his first major legislative victory. The vote was along party lines, with 51 Republicans voting in favor and 48 Democrats voting against it. The bill cuts the corporate tax rate from 35 percent to 21 percent and trimmed individual tax rates, but makes those cuts temporary in order to comply with Senate budget rules. Republicans say they anticipate that future Congresses will simply extend the individual cuts. The Senate also repealed Obamacare's individual mandate, partially making good on the GOP's repeated pledges to repeal the law, and opened up the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge ( ANWR ) for oil drilling, which is a long-sought goal of Alaska lawmakers and many other Republicans.
elections_181: The former President Bill Clinton warned that a Mitt Romney presidency would be calamitous for America and the world in a speech. Clinton said that Obama has earned a second term because of his steering of the economy through a “miserable situation” and “the alternative would be, in my opinion, calamitous for our country and the world.” Obama and Romney were focusing their message on economic opportunity. Polls show that economic trends are likely to determine the election, with Romney’s poor showing in May fueling some heartburn among supporters. Romney’s campaign had a fund-raising surge in May, collecting more than $76.8 million, nearly $17 million more than Obama. However, the surge in fund-raising came as the campaign and the Republican National Committee were in partnership, and as Romney began to make some inroads among outside political groups, particularly “super PACs.” Obama’s fund-raising efforts were not as strong, with his campaign and the Democratic National Committee raising a total of $60 million.
trade_46: The trade war between China and the US has escalated with China announcing retaliatory tariffs on US imports worth $ 60bn. This follows the US decision to raise tariffs on Chinese goods worth $ 200bn. The US Trade Representative’s office has said it plans to hold a public hearing next month on the possibility of imposing duties of up to 25% on a further $ 300bn worth of imports from China. Trump has said he will meet Chinese President Xi Jinping at a G20 summit in late June. The conflict has sent tremors through global markets, with the Dow Jones industrial average losing more than 600 points and the Nasdaq recording its worst day of 2019.
elections_410: A recount of votes in both the Florida U.S. Senate and governor races has been ordered after unofficial results showed both races too close to call. Republicans Rick Scott and Ron DeSantis have leads that have narrowed, but are still in front of Democrats Bill Nelson and Andrew Gillum, respectively. Counties that were hit hard by Hurricane Michael have already finished counting their ballots, while Broward County, which is heavily Democratic, is still working to tally its votes. The recount is a result of the close margins and the ongoing legal challenges that have been raised.
nsa_858: The National Security Agency (NSA) has been collecting and analyzing phone and email records of millions of Americans without a warrant for years, according to new data released by a former intelligence contractor. NSA officials claim that the data is used to prevent terrorist attacks, but critics say the program is a violation of privacy rights and that the NSA has engaged in illegal activity. The Obama administration has been under pressure to address the program and has promised to review it, but the latest revelations are likely to fuel further debate and calls for reform.
fiscal_cliff_418: The White House and Congress are at an impasse over taxes and government spending to avert the “fiscal cliff” that threatens to raise taxes and cut spending automatically in January, Reuters reported. No talks were set between the White House and congressional leaders on Thursday. Obama urged quick passage of legislation extending tax cuts for most Americans in a speech at a Pennsylvania toy factory. The Republican-controlled House has already passed legislation extending tax cuts for most Americans, but the matter has not come up for a vote in the Senate. Boehner said that no substantive progress had been made in the talks between the White House and the House over the past two weeks.
elections_62: The latest polls from Florida, Ohio, and Wisconsin show President Barack Obama and his Republican challenger Mitt Romney in a virtual tie. The numbers in Florida and Wisconsin are with in the polls' sampling error, and in Ohio Obama's margin is just outside the sampling error. The polls were taken before the Paul Ryan announcement, and the numbers have not changed significantly since then. The Republican ticket has not changed the dynamic of the race much, with Obama still leading Romney by a small margin.
europe_339: After the historic Brexit vote, promises made by politicians are falling apart. The UK voted to leave the European Union, and politicians are having a hard time figuring out the details of the exit. The Leave campaign made several promises, including that the UK would be able to control immigration and that the NHS would receive more money. However, none of these promises are likely to be met. The UK is also facing an economic crisis, as the pound has fallen and the stock market has plummeted. The situation is becoming increasingly chaotic, and politicians are struggling to maintain order.
us_senate_88: 1. The Senate Foreign Relations Committee has voted to recommend President Trump's nominee for Secretary of State, Mike Pompeo, for confirmation. 2. Pompeo is a former Kansas congressman and ex-CIA director who was nominated to replace Rex Tillerson. 3. Pompeo has been described as hawkish and has expressed views that are at odds with some of Trump's statements on the Iran nuclear deal and North Korea. 4. Despite some Democratic opposition, Pompeo has received support from several Republicans and some Democrats. 5. The vote on Pompeo's nomination is expected to be close, with some Republicans expressing reservations about his views on certain issues.
elections_599: Donald Trump is now in a desperate race to win the Republican presidential nomination. The New York primary on Tuesday is critical for him to secure the delegates he needs to win the nomination before the RNC convention in July. The polls suggest that Trump will win the primary in New York, but he is still struggling to win over enough voters to secure a majority of the delegates. Trump's opponents, Ted Cruz and John Kasich, are also campaigning hard in New York and could potentially deny him the nomination if they win enough delegates.
elections_463: Donald Trump is not participating in Thursday 's Republican debate on Fox News. Instead, he is holding a benefit event for veterans at the same time and place. Trump says he is not interested in participating in the debate because he feels he has already won all of them. He also feels that he has been mistreated by the network and its moderators. The debate has already been criticized by some for being overly negative and personal. Trump has been accused of using the event as a way to get free publicity. Many people are curious to see what Trump will say and do during the event.
politics_508: The controversy surrounding former Trump adviser Steve Bannon deepened on Thursday as one of his biggest financial backers publicly rebuked him and several “outsider” candidates championed by Bannon rushed to distance themselves from him after excerpts of his interviews with the author of a new book became public. The loss of support from Mercer, whose family has bankrolled several Bannon projects, could signal jeopardy for Bannon’s position at Breitbart, where Mercer has an ownership stake. Meanwhile, Trump has continued his attack on Bannon, calling him “a loser” who has “lost his mind” in a Wednesday statement. The president has also threatened legal action against the author of the book, Michael Wolff, for reporting on Bannon’s comments.
justice_department_768: The IRS scandal is involving a lot of legal talk and it seems that the agency is facing a lot of consequences. The acting commissioner of the IRS, Danny Werfel, is trying to clean house by replacing the supervisor who oversaw the agents involved in targeting tea party groups. The director of the exempt organizations division, Lois Lerner, was placed on administrative leave and then refuses to resign. This has caused confusion and anger among lawmakers, who are calling on her to be removed from office. The new acting commissioner has stated that he will move quickly to fix the conditions that led to the targeting scandal.
elections_616: In 2019, the Democrats gained control of both chambers of the Virginia Legislature and the governorship of Kentucky in a series of election contests that highlighted the party’s ability to win in red states. In Virginia, Democrats flipped six seats in the House and took a slim majority in the Senate, and in Kentucky, Democrat Andy Beshear narrowly defeated Republican Governor Matt Bevin. These victories came despite President Trump’s efforts to boost Republican candidates in the key races. The election results also showed the Democrats’ willingness to win seats in traditionally Republican areas by avoiding left-wing positions such as Medicare for All.
middle_east_409: Posted on 09/03/2013 Barack Obama and Bashar al-Assad of Syria are expected to come face-to-face on American television today. While Obama will make his case for a military strike on Syria, Assad will deny any involvement in the chemical weapons attack on civilians in his country last month. Obama's decision to appear on six networks has been criticized by some, as it may have been better for him to make his case to Congress and the American people through a series of written reports and testimony. However, Obama's decision to appear on television is a clear attempt to persuade the American public to support his position on Syria. The Obama administration hopes to use the opportunity to showcase the evidence they have gathered against Assad and to present a persuasive argument for a military strike.
media_bias_190: Facebook, which now has 1.6 billion monthly active users, has been accused of manipulating its trending news feature to exclude conservative articles and promote liberal ones. According to a former Facebook contractor, the platform routinely suppressed topics of interest to conservative readers, and several former Facebook "news curators" told Gizmodo that they were told to "inject" certain topics into the trending list, even if they weren't popular enough to warrant making the crucial list. Facebook has denied any political bias, but the allegations have raised concerns about the company's growing influence on what news gets read. The trending news feature, which shows popular topics and hashtags that are being talked about on Facebook, has become an influential designation that boosts traffic for what are deemed the hottest topics.
north_korea_26: US President Donald Trump has ramped up his rhetoric against North Korea, warning on Thursday that the country would face “ fire and fury ” if it attacked the US or one of its allies. Trump’s warning came after the North Korean regime warned on Tuesday that it would strike the Pacific territory of Guam if the US continued to threaten it. The US has been pursuing backchannel talks with North Korea, according to two US officials, while Trump has continued to threaten military action against the country. Meanwhile, the North Korean leader, Kim Jong Un, has warned that the US should not underestimate the country’s nuclear capabilities. The US and China are also at odds over the issue, with China calling on the US to calm tensions and reduce military action against North Korea.
elections_28: Republicans had a sweeping victory in Tuesday's midterm elections. They captured the Senate and gained seats in the House, marking the end of a Democratic four-year reign in Congress. The GOP reelected divisive governors in Florida, Michigan, Wisconsin, and Kansas, and won the governor's office in Massachusetts. In the House, Republicans defeated 36-year incumbent Nick Rahall in West Virginia and snuffed out South Florida Democrat Joe Garcia's congressional career after just a single term. The party's margin of control is certain to grow as the returns roll in.
isis_807: U.S. officials say U.S. airstrikes against the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria are proceeding despite intelligence gaps that stand in contrast to the networks of bases, spies and ground-based technology the U.S. had in place during past wars. The Islamic State group remains on the offensive in Iraq and Syria, where it still controls large sections. Human rights groups claim coalition airstrikes in both countries have killed as many as two dozen civilians.
north_korea_758: North Korea is reportedly developing a smaller, lighter and diversified nuclear arsenal and has threatened to use it in a military strike against the United States. In response, the U.S. is stationing more missile defense systems in the region and is considering a permanent presence in Guam. Meanwhile, the U.S. and China are working to diplomatically resolve the conflict, with Secretary of State John Kerry planning to meet with North Korea's neighbors next week. South Korea has responded to the threat by barring its workers from a jointly run factory complex in North Korea.
impeachment_706: President Donald Trump was acquitted on two articles of impeachment by the Senate on Wednesday, with 52 senators voting to acquit him of abuse of power and 53 voting to acquit him of obstruction of Congress. Only one Republican, Senator Susan Collins, joined Democrats in seeking testimony in the trial, and no House Republicans voted to impeach Trump. The trial ended on Tuesday, with Collins announcing she would vote to acquit Trump. The only other Republican to vote with Democrats, Senator Lisa Murkowski, announced she would also vote to acquit Trump on both articles of impeachment.
supreme_court_55: The Senate confirmation hearing for Supreme Court nominee Judge Brett Kavanaugh began Wednesday, with senators grilling him on his views on democracy, abortion, and the presidency. Kavanaugh, a conservative who has served on the federal appeals court in Washington, D.C. for 12 years, is seen as a potential threat to liberal rights and freedoms. He has already been accused of perjury by Democrats, who are skeptical of his qualifications to serve on the Supreme Court. The hearing is expected to last several days, with the final vote taking place in the coming weeks.
us_house_619: The first public hearing of the impeachment inquiry into President Trump is underway. William Taylor, the acting ambassador to Ukraine, and George Kent, the deputy assistant secretary of State for European and Eurasian affairs, are testifying. Taylor described an "irregular" foreign policy channel with Ukraine led by Giuliani and explained why he raised concerns with colleagues after learning that the White House was withholding security aid until Ukraine agreed to open investigations beneficial to Trump's reelection. Meanwhile, Marie Yovanovitch, a former ambassador to Ukraine, responded to GOP claims that Ukraine meddled in the 2016 U.S. election and said the military aid Trump endorsed has benefited Ukraine in its war against Russia.
healthcare_394: President Obama on Monday defended the Affordable Care Act and the problems that have plagued the central website launched earlier this month to sign up consumers, and appealed to the public to have patience as the site is being fixed. Obama stood front-and-center in the White House Rose Garden and said he would not excuse the problems with the site, but said consumers can apply by mail or phone. Officials from the Department of Health and Human Services on Sunday posted a blog on its site with some preliminary statistics and an assurance to Americans that officials are working around the clock to address the glitches. The president told his team the administration had to own up to the fact that there were no excuses for not having the health care website ready to operate on Day One.
terrorism_253: Terror attacks in Brussels, Belgium killed 31 people and injured 300 others. ISIS claimed responsibility for the attacks. Belgian federal prosecutors identified two of the attackers as brothers Khalid and Ibrahim El Bakraoui. They were involved in one of the airport attacks and the subway blast. Belgian authorities are actively hunting for the third suspect in the airport attack. The third suspect is believed to have planted the bomb at the airport and then left. The attack has left Belgium on high alert, with additional police and military patrols in place. Belgian authorities have also arrested several suspects in raids across the country.
healthcare_479: President Trump and House Speaker Paul Ryan faced a crushing defeat Friday as Republicans abandoned their effort to replace the Affordable Care Act. Trump had personally lobbied House members in an effort to win over the holdouts, but ultimately, he was unable to secure the necessary votes. The failure of the vote was a major setback for Trump, as it marked the first major legislative defeat of his presidency. Despite the setback, Trump and Ryan are not giving up on their goal of repealing the ACA, but they are shifting their focus to other issues, such as tax reform.
elections_54: In New York, both Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton scored significant victories in Tuesday's primaries. Trump received a majority of the vote statewide and is likely to win most of the remaining delegates, which would put him close to the 1,237 delegates needed for the nomination. Cruz and Sanders are struggling to keep up and may have to rely on superdelegates to win. The outcome was seen as a blow to Cruz and Sanders, who both face tough re-election challenges in November. However, the victory also gave Trump a boost of momentum and confidence, and he vowed to continue his campaign with renewed vigor.
elections_133: Roy Moore won the Republican Senate primary runoff in Alabama against Luther Strange, who was backed by Donald Trump. This was a blow to the GOP establishment, as Trump had initially supported Strange. The election was seen as a test of Trump's influence and his ability to rally his supporters. The outcome was not surprising, as Trump had been unpopular in Alabama before the election. The election also highlighted the deep divide within the Republican Party, as Strange was seen as more moderate than Moore.
supreme_court_232: President Trump is set to announce his pick for the Supreme Court Monday night, potentially setting the direction of the court for decades and sparking an acrimonious political battle. The four finalists are Brett Kavanaugh, Raymond Kethledge, Amy Coney Barrett, and Thomas Hardiman. Kavanaugh is the most conservative of the four and has been a staunch defender of the Second Amendment, religious freedom, and the right to bear arms. If confirmed, Kavanaugh would replace Anthony Kennedy, who was the swing vote on many of the court's most ideologically charged decisions, including Roe v. Wade.
north_korea_483: In a major diplomatic breakthrough, President Donald Trump has agreed to meet North Korean leader Kim Jong Un for the first time. The meeting is set to take place in two months and will focus on the North’s nuclear program. The announcement was made by South Korean National Security Adviser Chung Eui-yong after a visit to Pyongyang earlier this week. Kim reportedly expressed a desire for mutual denuclearization and normalized relations with the US. While some have expressed skepticism about the meeting, others see it as a positive step towards resolving the longstanding conflict on the Korean peninsula.
violence_in_america_208: Former Dallas police officer Amber Guyger was sentenced to 10 years in prison on Wednesday for murder after she shot and killed her unarmed black neighbor Botham Jean in September 2018. Amber Guyger was off-duty but still in uniform the night she killed Jean at the South Side Flats apartments just blocks from police headquarters. She said she mistook his apartment for hers and thought he was a burglar. After a day of testimony focused on how long Guyger would spend in prison, Jean’s 18-year-old brother said in his victim-impact statement that he wished she did not have to serve any time at all. Instead, he said, he wanted for Guyger what his older brother would have wanted. Botham Jean’s son Brandt Jean hugged Guyger after the sentence was announced, an unexpected moment of forgiveness inside the courtroom.
great_britain_379: Margaret Thatcher , a towering figure in post-war British and world politics who served as the country's prime minister from 1975 to 1990, has died at the age of 87 . During her time in power, Thatcher emphasized moral absolutism, nationalism, and the rights of the individual versus the state, famously declaring "There is no such thing as society" in 1987. She also presided over a period of economic and social transformation, privatizing the state sector and implementing policies that reduced unemployment. Thatcher's legacy remains highly controversial, with some revering her as a savior who rescued Britain from ruin and laid the groundwork for an extraordinary economic renaissance, while others criticize her for her hardline approach, which they say ushered in an era of greed and inequality.
elections_739: In the 2016 presidential race, the Republican nominee, Donald Trump, has been criticized for his refusal to say whether he believes President Barack Obama was born in the United States. At a campaign event on Friday, Trump finally conceded that Obama was born in the U.S., but he also accused Hillary Clinton of raising questions about Obama's citizenship during the 2008 campaign. This admission comes after Trump's aides and allies have been pressuring him to disavow the theories that fueled his political rise. Despite this, Trump has continued to play coy about the issue, often saying in interviews that the issue doesn't matter anymore. The shift in Trump's stance comes after Kellyanne Conway, a respected GOP pollster, was installed as his campaign manager in a leadership shakeup last month. While Trump has had lapses, he has generally been more restrained, even taking a pass on health conspiracy theories after Clinton nearly collapsed following a pneumonia diagnosis.
elections_93: Sen. Ted Cruz announced on Monday that he is running for the Republican presidential nomination in 2016, making him the first major candidate to officially toss his hat in the ring. While the election is still a long way off, there are several compelling reasons why Cruz should be considered a strong GOP presidential candidate for 2016. Cruz is off to an early start, has strong Tea Party support, has been one of the party's most outspoken opponents of Obamacare, has a strong legal background, and could appeal to disillusioned voters. He is also seen as more independent than other potential GOP candidates, as shown by his defiance of party leaders on immigration.
impeachment_370: The U.S. Senate on Wednesday began the presidential impeachment trial of President Donald Trump, with Republicans quickly abandoning their plans to cram opening arguments into two days. Trump’s legal team is defending him on the grounds that he has done nothing wrong and that he can legally extract personal concessions from foreign leaders. The Senate is expected to hear from witnesses, including former Trump adviser John Bolton, in the coming days.
politics_175: President-elect Donald Trump ’ s transition team has deployed “ landing parties ” to federal agencies responsible for national security, and offered the post of White House national security adviser to retired Lt. Gen. Michael T. Flynn. Sources on the president-elect’s transition team say Romney is under consideration for a top cabinet position in the Trump administration. Trump and vice-president-elect Mike Pence were huddled at Trump Tower in New York to work on key appointments as the US Senate was due to resume business in a still shellshocked Washington. The departure of former Republican congressman Mike Rogers from the president-elect’s transition team offered the latest clue that the transition is going to be every bit as bumpy as feared. A week after his election, Trump and vice-president-elect Mike Pence were huddled at Trump Tower in New York to work on key appointments as the US Senate was due to resume business in a still shellshocked Washington. Trump has offered the post of White House national security adviser to retired Lt. Gen. Michael T. Flynn. elections_448: The Republican establishment, or at least some of it, may be coming to terms with the possibility that Donald Trump will be the GOP presidential nominee. Palin, who has spoken openly about her anger with the press and Republican Party leaders, appeared to recognize that her endorsement marked a moment of comeback. Meanwhile, Cruz continued to attack Trump's character and record, telling reporters that he hopes anyone but Cruz wins his state's first-in-the-nation caucuses.
healthcare_3: President Obama on Thursday apologized to Americans who are losing health insurance despite his repeated and emphatic promises that it wouldn’t happen. About 5 percent of Americans have plans through the individual insurance market, and as many as two-thirds of them could lose coverage because it doesn’t comply with the Affordable Care Act’s standards. The situation has led to a backlash on Capitol Hill, with lawmakers on both sides advocating bills that would allow consumers to keep their coverage regardless of whether it meets the law’s standards.
healthcare_364: The Obama administration is still struggling to convince the public that the Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as Obamacare, is more than a series of policy cancellations and website hiccups. The first month of enrollment through the federal HealthCare.gov site resulted in only 106,185 sign-ups, far below the administration’s initial hopes and estimates. In addition to the low sign-ups, the website has been plagued with technical problems that have prevented many consumers from completing the enrollment process. The Obama administration is scrambling to fix the problems and hopes to have the site running smoothly for most people by the end of the month. Meanwhile, Republicans continue their attacks on the ACA, arguing that the enrollment figures demonstrate the law’s failure and calling for its repeal.
violence_in_america_747: The Navy Yard shooting has raised questions about the security clearance system used by the military and contractors. Aaron Alexis, the gunman, had a valid building pass that allowed him to enter the base. The building pass was granted to him as part of his job as a contractor. The security clearance process has been criticized for being too lenient and prone to human error. The Navy is reviewing its own security procedures in response to the shooting. The Defense Department is also reviewing physical security and access at all U.S. defense installations worldwide.
us_senate_126: In a rare move, the Senate silenced Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D-MA) during a debate over the nomination of Jeff Sessions (R-AL) to serve as Trump's attorney general. The move came after Warren read a letter from Coretta Scott King, opposing Sessions' nomination for a federal judgeship in 1986. Sessions was confirmed as Trump's attorney general Wednesday evening. The incident sparked a national debate about the role of the Senate in regulating nominations and the rights of senators to speak freely.
elections_581: In the final presidential debate, Obama and Romney discussed domestic and foreign policy issues. The candidates presented their visions for the country, but did not defend their records extensively. The debate was marked by a lack of animosity, with both candidates focusing on making their case to voters. The closing argument phase of the campaign has begun, with both campaigns looking to solidify their message and sway undecided voters. The debate was also a chance for Obama to restore his lead in the polls, which have been tightening in recent weeks.
impeachment_808: President Trump was acquitted by the Senate in his impeachment trial, ending a contentious and divisive process that began last year. The vote was largely along party lines, with only one Republican senator voting to convict him. Trump has maintained his innocence throughout the process and has used the acquittal as a political victory. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, who led the impeachment efforts, has not yet commented on the outcome.
elections_447: From the article: On Tuesday, six states held primary elections, and the Republican establishment appears to be winning its battle against the tea party. The success of the establishment candidates was attributed to their ability to run smart campaigns, benefiting from the tutelage of top political consultants. supreme_court_847: Sen. Susan Collins from Maine has announced that she will vote for Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh. Her decision paves the way for his confirmation vote, which is expected to occur Saturday. Collins said she believes that the allegations against Kavanaugh fail to meet the “more likely than not” standard, and that she does not believe these charges can prevent him from serving on the court. The Senate has already ended debate on Kavanaugh’s nomination after a renewed FBI background investigation did not corroborate the allegations against him. The confirmation vote is a contentious issue, with Democrats and Republicans holding different views on Kavanaugh’s qualifications and his stance on issues such as Roe v. Wade. Collins’ decision to vote for Kavanaugh has sparked controversy, with some people arguing that she is betraying the Me Too movement by dismissing Ford’s allegations.
supreme_court_830: In a blow to President Donald Trump, the Supreme Court refused to hear the administration's challenge to a lower court ruling blocking it from winding down the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program. The decision means the 9th Circuit Court of Appeals will continue to review the case, which could ease some pressure on Congress to quickly come up with a legislative solution. The fight over DACA, which provides protections to undocumented immigrants en masse, has been ongoing since 2012. Trump has set March 5 as the end date for the program, while calling on Congress to come up with a legislative fix. Republicans like Trump have argued that DACA is unconstitutional, but the Supreme Court rarely hears a case before a lower appeals court has considered it.
elections_645: Donald Trump has announced that he will not be participating in the upcoming GOP presidential primary debate hosted by Fox News. The decision was made after the debate lineup was announced, and Trump accused the network of treating him unfairly. Trump has cited concerns with one of the debate moderators, Megyn Kelly, but the network said she will be on the debate stage. The debate will take place on Thursday in Des Moines, Iowa, and will feature eight candidates. The decision by Trump to skip the debate has sparked debate among pundits and politicians, with some praising his decision and others criticizing him for being afraid of Kelly. The debate is a critical moment in the campaign, as it will be the last before the Iowa caucuses on Monday.
race_and_racism_746: News Summary: The Trayvon Martin verdict has sparked a heated debate around the country. The acquittal of George Zimmerman in the shooting death of the teenager has brought up racial issues and calls for the repeal of "stand your ground" laws. The ACLU has been at the center of the debate, with some members calling for the repeal of these laws, while others are hesitant. President Obama has also weighed in, saying that race may have played a role in the case and criticizing the laws. The Justice Department is investigating whether Zimmerman violated Martin's civil rights, and many are calling for federal charges.
terrorism_477: The FBI has released photos and video of two men suspected in the Boston Marathon bombing that killed three and injured nearly 180. The men, walking single file on Boylston Street toward the finish line, were seen carrying black backpacks. One wore a white baseball cap and the other a black one. The FBI said one of the men was seen leaving his bag "within minutes" at the site of the second explosion. The bureau is asking for the public's help identifying the suspects.
elections_662: Texas Senator Ted Cruz announced his candidacy for president Monday night, becoming the first major Republican contender in the 2016 race. supreme_court_257: The Senate should censure Sen. Dianne Feinstein for her role in events surrounding Brett Kavanaugh's nomination, according to U.S. Supreme Court Chief Justice John Roberts. elections_294: Based on the latest polls, Donald Trump is currently leading Ted Cruz in the Republican primary race in Iowa. state_department_386: The nomination of Rex Tillerson to be the next Secretary of State has provoked controversy both within the Trump administration and among foreign policy observers. Tillerson, a former CEO of ExxonMobil, has a history of doing business in Russia and close ties to Vladimir Putin. Some see Tillerson's nomination as a sign that the Trump administration is seeking to improve relations with Russia, while others view it as a dangerous departure from traditional U.S. foreign policy. Tillerson's nomination has also raised questions about conflicts of interest and his ability to serve as a credible advocate for American interests in the face of Russia's human rights abuses and aggression in Ukraine and Syria.
